fdd:description.p: Variant of the TIFF format that uses 64-bit offsets thereby supporting files up to 18,000 petabytes in size, vastly transcending TIFF's normal 4 GB limit. Since the format also supports all of the normal features and header tags of TIFF_6 and the extended metadata offered by GeoTIFF, it provides good service in the GIS domain, medical imaging, and other applications that employ large scanners or cameras.

One limiting factor for TIFF is file size. As described in Use and Export BigTIFF Files, "in the standard TIFF format, [the] offset is specified by a 32-bit integer (4 bytes). The largest offset that can be specified is thus 232 bytes, or 4 GB." The post BigTIFF - Exceeding the 4 GB Limit from 2018 adds that "most desktop computers had about 2-4 MBytes of RAM at that time so a 4 GB limit seemed to have plenty of head room." But this 4 GB maximum file size limit is a hindrance when dealing with detailed, complex or large images. In 2004, BigTIFF was founded which changed the offset value as a 64-bit integer (8 bytes) which extends the theoretical maximum file size to 18,000 PB (petabytes).

As explained in Welcome to the BigTIFF version of the libtiff library and The BigTIFF File Format, there are several significant differences between the the format of a BigTIFF file and a standard TIFF file:

ul.li: In the file header, BigTIFF is declared as 0x002B (43) at offset 2 bytes as compared with the TIFF version of 0x002A (42)
Bytesize of offsets is always 8 in BigTIFF (not present in TIFF)
IFD (Image File Directory) takes up 20 bytes in BigTIFF as opposed to 12 in TIFF

fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:shortDescription: A variant TIFF format, BigTIFF transcends TIFF's 4 GB TIFF limit using 64-bit offsets thereby supporting files up to 18,000 petabytes in size.
fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:productionPhase: Most often an initial-state or middle-state format; may serve as final-state format.

fdd:localUse.fdd:experience: BigTIFF is strongly recommended as the primary format for images captured in the FADGI-authored Guidelines for IRENE System Products for Long Term Retention: Deliverable Packages for Imaged Audio Systems.
fdd:localUse.fdd:preference: See the Library of Congress Recommended Formats Statement for format preferences for still image works.

fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:documentation: The BigTIFF File Format specification is provided online by AWare Systems.

fdd:adoption.p: BigTIFF is supported by the following software libraries:

ul.li: GDAL - Geospatial Data Abstraction Library maintained by Open Source Geospatial Foundation (OSGeo). The GDAL library is used in other software. For example, in the TIFF (Tagged Image File Format) Reader/Writer in Safe Software's FME (Feature Manipulation Engine).

LibTIFF, version 4.0 and later, a software toolkit available via several mirror sites as of May 2020: LibTIFF at simplesystems.org; LibTIFF at maptools.org; and LibTIFF at gitlab.io. The support for BigTIFF in the LibTIFF toolkit originated with Aperio Technologies, Inc. See Aperio Implements BigTIFF, Donates Enhancements to Public Domain (May 3, 2007) from BusinessWire.

fdd:adoption.p: BigTIFF is supported by many specialist imaging applications, e.g, for geospatial and biomedical use. Some general image editing applications can read very large images, but have problems saving them. The following software applications support BigTIFF images:

ul.li: Avenza’s Geographic Imager. See Geographic Imager Raster/Reference Formats.

Global Mapper. A limited-feature evaluation version of this software is available for download (also formerly known as USGS Digital Data Viewer: dlgv32 Pro). See Supported File Formats in Global Mapper.
MATLAB. See BigTIFF support in MATLAB.
ArcGIS, Introduced in 10.0. See Supported raster dataset file formats
STIFF, an astronomical pipeline software that converts scientific FITS images to the more popular TIFF format for illustration purposes.
Openslide. See Virtual slide formats understood by OpenSlide
A variety of other imaging systems for pathology and histology. Most software designed to render or manipulate geospatial raster images.

fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:licensingAndPatents: The BigTIFF enhancements in Aperio’s libtiff were made by Ole Eichhorn (formerly of Aperio Technologies, acquired by Leica Biosystems in 2012) and (in the words of the bigtiff.org web page) "are donated to the public domain, in gratitude to Sam Leffler, Silicon Graphics, Joris Van Damme, AWare Systems, Frank Warmerdam, Andrey Kisley, Mike Welles, and all who have worked on libtiff over the years to provide such a great tool. The aperio libtiff changes were published on an 'as is' basis and neither Ole Eichhorn nor Aperio Technologies make any warranty as to their fitness for any intended use." See also TIFF_6.
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:transparency: Wrapper is as transparent as TIFF_6

fdd:selfDocumentation.p: Accessibility for still image content is often supported by the use of alt text when displayed on the web. The carriage of this data is typically not embedded in the file itself but rather in the HTML code. TIFF files have moderate support for accessibility features through the use of embedded metadata in TIFF tags. For example, ImageDescription tag (code 270) describes the content of the image but this may not be accessible to screen readers.

fdd:stillImageQF.fdd:normalImage: LibTiff 4.0 reads ClassicTIFF and BigTIFF both, and the application does not need to be aware which TIFF version an opened file is.

fdd:clarity.p: Excellent support for images with very high spatial resolution.

fdd:gisQF.fdd:normalGIS: BigTIFF is supported in the GDAL - Geospatial Data Abstraction Library maintained by Open Source Geospatial Foundation (OSGeo). See also GeoTIFF_1_0.

fdd:filenameExtension.fdd:note: Mentioned in the AWare systems specification. .tif appears to be used most frequently.

fdd:values.fdd:note: NARA File Format Preservation Plan ID has no corresponding entry as of November 2024.

fdd:notes.fdd:general: BigTIFF is supported in the GDAL - Geospatial Data Abstraction Library maintained by the Open Source Geospatial Foundation (OSGeo). The BigTIFF format is also adopted by large format scanners, medical imaging, astronomy, and in other fields of endeavor.

fdd:history.p: The BigTIFF design was first proposed in 2004 by Joris Van Damme of AWare Systems and refined on the AWare Systems mailing list. Contributors to the AWare Systems design discussion included Lynn Quam, Frank Warmerdam, Chris Cox, Rob Tillaart, Dan Smith, Bob Freisenhahn, Andrey Kiselev, Phillip Crews, and Gerben Vos. In 2007 Aperio released a version of libtiff which supported BigTIFF files. The BigTIFF enhancements in Aperio’s libtiff were made by Ole Eichhorn, then of Aperio Technologies (taken over by Leica Biosystems in 2012) and (in the words of the bigtiff.org web page) "were donated to the public domain, in gratitude to Sam Leffler, Silicon Graphics, Joris Van Damme, Aware Systems, Frank Warmerdam, Andrey Kisley, Mike Welles, and all who had worked on libtiff over the years to provide such a great tool. The aperio libtiff changes were published on an 'as is' basis and neither Ole Eichhorn nor Aperio Technologies made or make any warranty as to their fitness for any intended use. In 2007, WeoGeo, Safe Software, Leica Geosystems, and ESRI sponsored Joris Van Damme & Frank Warmerdam (the libtiff and gdal maintainers) with a project for updating libtiff to LibTiff 4.0."(Link via Internet Archive)

The first code to support BigTIFF Code is available from bigtiff.org (formerly at www.aperio.com/bigtiff). This was a fork based on earlier libtiff code (version 3.8.2), with a latest version as of December 2011. The first official version of libtiff to support BigTIFF was 4.0.0 (link via Internet Archive).

As of May 2020, the primary official source for the libtiff library is at http://www.simplesystems.org/libtiff/ with version 4.1.0 being the latest stable version. A software archive is at https://download.osgeo.org/libtiff/. Versions older than 4.0.4 are available at https://download.osgeo.org/libtiff/old/.

fdd:urlReference.comment: Specification as provided by AWare Systems.
Support for BigTIFF, for files larger than 4 GB, started with version 4.0 of LibTIFF.

Supports most forms of TIFF and GeoTIFF files for reading. Somewhat fewer varieties can be written.
When built with internal libtiff or with libtiff >= 4.0, GDAL also supports reading and writing BigTIFF files.
